thread.title: 30 things you didn't know about 'Star Wars'
thread.title_full: 30 things you didn't know about 'Star Wars' - San Antonio Express-News

author: Joshua Fechter
title: 30 things you didn't know about 'Star Wars'
text:
Image 1 of / 32 32
Think you know everything about "Star Wars?"
Scroll through the slideshow for 30 facts to test your knowledge about the iconic fantasy franchise.
Think you know everything about "Star Wars?"
Scroll through the...
Image 2 of 32 1. Tupac Shakur apparently read for the role of Mace Windu in "The Phantom Menace" before he died in September 1996, according to former Death Row Records engineer Rick Clifford. The part went to Samuel L. Jackson.
Source: Rolling Stone
1. Tupac Shakur apparently read for the role of Mace Windu in "The... Image 3 of 32 2. Samuel L. Jackson claims that his character Mace Windu in the "Star Wars" prequel trilogy has the words "bad m r" carved into his purple lightsaber, recalling the inscription on Jules Winnfield's wallet in "Pulp Fiction."
Source: BBC/YouTube
Photo: File/Lucasfilm/Getty Images 2. Samuel L. Jackson claims that his character Mace Windu in the... Image 4 of 32 3. At the behest of his daughters, George Lucas filmed an NSYNC cameo for "Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones." He later cut the scene.
Source: MTV
Photo: Jeff Kravitz, FilmMagic 3. At the behest of his daughters, George Lucas filmed an NSYNC... Image 5 of 32 4. Carrie Fisher complained that her costumes in the first two films weren't sexy enough. In response, costume designers crafted the infamous "slave bikini" used during the Jabba the Hutt sequence in "Return of the Jedi."
Source: The FW
Photo: Courtesy Photo 4. Carrie Fisher complained that her costumes in the first two... Image 6 of 32 5. Han Solo's a bit of a cradle robber. Harrison Ford was 37 years old when "The Empire Strikes Back," which features the famous romance between Han Solo and Princess Leia, hit theaters May 21, 1980.
Carrie Fisher's age at the time? 23.
Photo: Handout, McClatchy-Tribune News Service 5. Han Solo's a bit of a cradle robber. Harrison Ford was 37 years... Image 7 of 32 6. Chewbacca's distinctive voice is a mix of bears, lions, walruses and badgers among other dying animals.
Source: Mashable
Photo: handout CD 6. Chewbacca's distinctive voice is a mix of bears, lions,... Image 8 of 32 7. Despite its groundbreaking special effects and wide vistas, the first "Star Wars" film was made on a meager budget of $11 million.
In today's dollars, that's a bit more than $46 million. For some perspective, the effects-heavy 2012 movie "The Avengers" cost $220 million to make.
Source: Box Office Mojo / U.S. Inflation Calculator
Photo: File 7. Despite its groundbreaking special effects and wide vistas, the... Image 9 of 32 8. When handmaiden Padmé and Queen Amidala — both played by Natalie Portman — appear together in scenes in "The Phantom Menace," Portman portrays Padmé while a young Keira Knightley plays a handmaiden disguised as Amidala.
Source: iMDB
Photo: File 8. When handmaiden Padmé and Queen Amidala — both played by... Image 10 of 32 9. Yoda, the wise Jedi master, was almost played by a monkey carrying a cane and wearing a mask in "The Empire Strikes Back."
Source: The Wrap
Photo: 1996-98 AccuSoft Inc. 9. Yoda, the wise Jedi master, was almost played by a monkey... Image 11 of 32 10. Harrison Ford received only $10,000 for his performance as Han Solo in "Star Wars," later renamed "Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope."
Source: TheRichest
10. Harrison Ford received only $10,000 for his performance as Han... Image 12 of 32 11. While filming "The Phantom Menace," Ewan McGregor kept making the iconic lightsaber sound while filming fight sequences, despite the fact that George Lucas explained to him that the sounds would be added in during post-production.
McGregor's explanation? "I keep getting carried away."
Source: iMDB
Photo: File/Lucasfilm 11. While filming "The Phantom Menace," Ewan McGregor kept making... Image 13 of 32 12. George Lucas got the name for the adorable droid R2-D2 while working on his 1973 movie "American Graffiti." Sound editor Walter Murch asked for "R2-D2, the abbreviation for "reel two, dialogue track two." Lucas apparently lurched up, asked Murch to repeat himself and said, "What a great name!"
Source: Film Freak Central
Photo: File/Getty Images 12. George Lucas got the name for the adorable droid R2-D2 while... Image 14 of 32 13. Researchers believe that Anakin Skywalker — who murders countless children and aliens and chokes out his pregnant wife — meets at least six of the nine criteria for borderline personality disorder.
Source: LiveScience
13. Researchers believe that Anakin Skywalker — who murders... Image 15 of 32 14. The alien E.T. from Steven Spielberg's 1982 movie "E.T. the Extra Terrestrial" make a slight cameo in "The Phantom Menace" where three similar aliens appear in the Galactic Senate.
The characters' appearance is not intended to imply a connection between the two films, but is the result of an arrangement between Spielberg and George Lucas by which the alien would be included in Lucas' next "Star Wars" movie after Yoda appeared in "E.T."
Source: Star Wars Wikia Photo: handout email 14. The alien E.T. from Steven Spielberg's 1982 movie "E.T. the... Image 16 of 32 15. Steven Spielberg, despite having nothing to do with "Star Wars," has made millions of dollars off of the franchise because of a bet made with George Lucas in 1977.
Lucas, believing Spielberg's "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" would be more successful than "Star Wars," promised Spielberg 2.5 percent of his movie's profits in exchange for the same percentage from "Close Encounters." Spielberg got the better deal.
Source: Celebrity Net Worth
Photo: Evan Agostini, Associated Press 15. Steven Spielberg, despite having nothing to do with "Star... Image 17 of 32 16. Mark Hamill suffered severe facial trauma and scarring during a car accident prior to filming "The Empire Strikes Back." That's why the film opens with Luke Skywalker being kidnapped and mauled by a Wampa, a "Star Wars" version of a yeti.
Source: Buzzfeed
Photo: Associated Press 16. Mark Hamill suffered severe facial trauma and scarring during... Image 18 of 32 17. Liam Neeson, who played Qui-Gon Jinn in "The Phantom Menace," was too tall to fit through doorways constructed for that movie's filming.
Set designers incurred an additional $150,000 in production costs to accommodate the six-foot-four actor.
Source: IMDb
17. Liam Neeson, who played Qui-Gon Jinn in "The Phantom Menace,"... Image 19 of 32 18. George Lucas considered Japanese actor Toshiro Mifune, star of “Seven Samurai” and “Rashomon,” for the role of Obi-Wan Kenobi in the original trilogy.
That role instead went to Alec Guinness (right), who received an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his performance.
Source: Star Wars Year by Year: A Visual Chronicle
Photo: File/Lucasfilm/Associated Press 18. George Lucas considered Japanese actor Toshiro Mifune, star of... Image 20 of 32 19. George Lucas wanted Steven Spielberg to direct "Return of the Jedi." However, the Directors Guild of America prevented Spielberg from directing the film, citing feuds between Lucas, Spielberg and the guild.
Source: Grantland Photo: Universal/Getty Images 19. George Lucas wanted Steven Spielberg to direct "Return of the... Image 21 of 32 20. Ewan McGregor, who played Obi-Wan Kenobi in the prequel trilogy, isn’t the first in his family to be in a Star Wars movie: his uncle Denis Lawson (left) played Wedge Antilles in the original trilogy.
Photo: Edwin Marcow, AP Photo/Edwin Marcow 20. Ewan McGregor, who played Obi-Wan Kenobi in the prequel... Image 22 of 32 21. Despite mixed audience response about the furry creatures, the word “Ewok” is never said out loud during “Return of the Jedi.”
Photo: Lucasfilm 21. Despite mixed audience response about the furry creatures, the... Image 23 of 32 22. "Return of the Jedi," the final installment in the original trilogy, was almost named "Revenge of the Jedi" because George Lucas felt the original title was too weak. He then switched back to the original title because he believed a proper Jedi wouldn't take revenge.
Source: Empire of Dreams: The Story of the Star Wars Trilogy
Photo: Getty Images 22. "Return of the Jedi," the final installment in the original... Image 24 of 32 23. "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan" had to change its title from "Vengeance of Khan" because the studio wanted to avoid confusion with "Revenge of the Jedi." That move proved for naught when the "Star Wars" flick's title was changed to "Return of the Jedi."
Source: iMDB
23. "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan" had to change its title from... Image 25 of 32 24. Harrison Ford wanted Han Solo to sacrifice himself and die in "Return of the Jedi," but George Lucas rejected the idea against the wishes of fellow screenwriter Lawrence Kasdan.
Source: Wired
Photo: Ethan Miller, Getty Images 24. Harrison Ford wanted Han Solo to sacrifice himself and die in... Image 26 of 32 25. The famous "No, I am your father" line from "The Empire Strikes Back" was kept secret from everyone except for Mark Hamill, George Lucas and director Irvin Kershner.
David Prowse, the actor in the Darth Vader suit, read the line: "You don't know the truth: Obi-Wan killed your father!"
Source: Sound & Vision
25. The famous "No, I am your father" line from "The Empire... Image 27 of 32 26. In a proposed ending to "Return of the Jedi," Luke Skywalker takes his father’s mask after he dies, puts it on and proclaims, “Now, I am Vader.”
Lucas ultimately favored a happier ending.
Source: io9
26. In a proposed ending to "Return of the Jedi," Luke Skywalker... Image 28 of 32 27. The filming of the first "Star Wars" movie in Tunisia almost sparked an actual war: the Libyan government believed that one of the film's Sandcrawlers , positioned near the Libya-Tunisia border, was a military vehicle and threatened the Tunisian government with military movements.
Tunisian officials asked Lucas to move the model.
Source: Mic
Photo: Uncredited, Associated Press 27. The filming of the first "Star Wars" movie in Tunisia almost... Image 29 of 32 28. Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining" caused delays on the filming of “The Empire Strikes Back” after a fire burned down an entire soundstage used to shoot the former. Kubrick, a notoriously meticulous filmmaker, took over some of the space used to shoot "Empire," taking weeks to finish his shoots.
Source: Mental Floss
Photo: Archive Photos, Getty Images 28. Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining" caused delays on the filming... Image 30 of 32 29. George Lucas almost didn't cast Harrison Ford as Han Solo, seeing auditions from Al Pacino, Kurt Russell (pictured) and Christopher Walken among others. However, Lucas liked the way Ford fed lines to other auditioning actors and gave him the part.
Source: Mental Floss
29. George Lucas almost didn't cast Harrison Ford as Han Solo,... Image 31 of 32 30. David Fincher — the stylistic director of films such as "Fight Club," "Zodiac" and "Gone Girl" — was neighbors with George Lucas in San Anselmo and later worked for Lucas' visual effects company Industrial Light and Magic. While there, he worked as an assistant cameraman and matte photographer on "Return of the Jedi" and "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom."
Source: The Independent
Photo: 20TH CENTURY FOX 30. David Fincher — the stylistic director of films such as... Image 32 of 32 30 things you didn't know about 'Star Wars' 1 / 32 Back to Gallery There's probably no other franchise in film history as packed with crazy and weird trivia for fans to obsess over and nitpick than "Star Wars."
But, even die-hard fans of the film series might not have heard some of these strange and fascinating tidbits.
And, with the looming release of "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" on Dec. 18, non-fans might want to get a leg up on their friends who likely won't shut up about that movie for weeks after its release.
Think you know everything there is to know about "Star Wars?"
Brush up on your trivia with 30 facts you may have missed about the beloved galaxy far, far away.
jfechter@mySA.com
Twitter: @JFreports
